seg.seg: ... He will make obvious the illusion [lit. wrong picture] of [bodily] form. For sure, the monster of death (will swallow) [the bodily forms] one after the other ...
... He protects (the beings (?)) from separation. But throwing ... definitetly ceases for him. Being(s) of that sort ...
... through the fruit of (meditations) having been reborn in the state-of-neither-consciousness-nor-unconsciousness [Skt. naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatana-], there indeed to these ones
... as it were moment after moment it ceases for them. Until the following (they will) take birth in the Avīci-hell ...
... divine [and] human glory is not approved by me. And in addition: In [the tune] bahuprakāra: «All ...
... the world (?), the impurity, this indeed [is] hateful (?). The possessions [are] the cause of greed, of pride, of folly, of avarice.
... (I) [who] represses the afflictions [lit. making the containment of the afflictions], having praised immortality [and] the Nirvāṇa for the good ones; towards that [goal] ...
... I will search the way.» 1. Having been rejoiced, these disciples with añjali gesture (speak to) the Bodhisattva
... In [the tune] ...cyen: «Bearing a tuft of hair between the eyebrows, white like the moon, (making) visible ...
... surrounded by rays wide as a fathom, big through goodness, your na(ture) of Buddhahood (we venerate (?)) ...
...» 1. «In every way we will cherish the wish (to be present) where[ever] (in) the world you (will appear) as a Buddhalord ...
... göttliche [und] menschliche Würde wird von mir nicht gelobt
... divine [and/or] human dignity is not praised by me.
...» (Having heard that), the (Bodhi)sattva says: «Well met! [lit. excellent juncture.] And who is the being who (having) cro(ssed) the jungle of many dangers ... ?»

p.note: This manuscript has consistent spelling of double virāma (i.e. with stroke and dot) with the remarkable exception of phrases: camak\ camak\• 'one after the other' (a1). Accordingly, ślak\• śkaṃ 'and in addition' (a5) was not interpreted as a phrase.
Unlike in the edition in 34, recto and verso side have to be reversed, according to Siegling, pers. copy.
Word separation is uncertain. Note that Siegling, pers. copy took tsaranämak as a single word.

Siegling, pers. copy proposed to resore (omä)sk(e)nāśśi 'evils', but the recorded gen.pl. is omäskenäśśi. In addition, (plya)sk(e)nāśśi 'meditations' seems to fit the context better, since Naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatana is reached by meditation.
In 304 the verb form is restored as 3.sg. middle present e(ntsäṣtär). Alternatively, Siegling, pers. copy proposed to restore the 3.pl. middle subjunctive e(ntsantär).

The verbal form artär does not belong to ār(ā)- 'to cease' (attested twice in this text) nor to ar- 'to evoke', but is a 3.sg. middle present from ārtā- 'to love', as per 260; however, pace Schmidt, it is not due to a misspelling of expected artatär, but rather an analogical form, i.e. with syncope in analogy from the other persons.
The hapax waro can be seen as an adjective derived from a noun *war being the match of TB 'hatred, enmity'.

The form before (a)kappi is most likely a sandhi variant of a disyllabic word ending in -i. The remnants of the last akṣara are compatible with 〈ṣya〉. Therefore, one may conceive a form of śoṣi 'world'; it may then be a compound meaning 'the impurity of the world'.
The tune name cannot be restored, the meter has 20+22+10+15 syllables with the rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, and d=8/7.
